🎯 Key Takeaways for quick navigation:  00:49 📐 An equation for a plane is of the form ax + by + cz = d, where a, b, c, and d are numbers, expressing the condition for a point to be in the plane. 03:20 🛑 A point P is in a plane when the dot product of vector OP and the normal vector N is 0, leading to the equation x + 5y + 10z = 0 for a given normal vector N = <1,5,10>. 06:50 🔄 Shifting the plane to pass through a specific point P0 involves adjusting the equation, resulting in x - 5y - 10z = -3, where -3 is derived from plugging the coordinates of P0 into the equation. 10:08 ⚙️ Coefficients in the plane equation ax + by + cz = d correspond to the normal vector, and the constant term measures the distance from the origin or a parallel plane. 13:56 ↕️ A vector is perpendicular to a plane if its dot product with the normal vector of the plane is 0, and it's parallel to the plane if perpendicular to the normal vector. 17:52 🌐 Solving a linear system of equations (3x3) involves finding points where the corresponding planes intersect; solutions can be a point, a line, or infinitely many points. 20:04 ⛔ No solution occurs when the line of intersection of two planes is parallel to the third plane; two subcases exist, one with the line contained in the third plane (infinitely many solutions) and one where the line is parallel but not contained (no solution). 28:45 ➡️ The geometric significance of the plane x y z = 1, 2, or 3 depends on whether these planes intersect, are parallel, or coincide. 31:19 🛩️ Equation x y z = 0 implies the plane passes through the origin, while changing constants leads to parallel planes. 32:14 📏 The constant term in the plane equation, D, represents how far the plane is moved from the origin, considering the length of the normal vector. 34:33 ❓ Matrix A is invertible if its determinant is not zero, and the inverse is found by dividing the adjoint matrix by the determinant. 35:30 🔄 Matrix A has an inverse when determinant is not zero, representing the usual case where three planes intersect in a point. 38:01 🏠 Homogeneous systems (B = 0) always have the trivial solution (0,0,0), and determinant of A determines solvability. 39:42 🎚️ If determinant of A is zero, the system may have either no solution or infinitely many solutions, depending on further elimination steps. 48:06 🌐 For a system AX = B, if determinant of A is not zero, there's a unique solution (X = A inverse B); if zero, planes are parallel, resulting in either no or infinitely many solutions.  Made with HARPA AI

This and the previous lectures are a great precursor to Gilbert Strang's 18.06 course. Provides a visually and conceptually clear understanding of determinants, inverse matrices and the solutions from using inverse matrices. It is so nice to be able to figure things out by visualizing instead of memorizing rules and equations.
22:44 If all the coefficients of three equations are zero, any (x, y, z) is a solution to the system.

At 15:00, plugging in the vector <1,2,-1> into the equation is basically doing the dot product with the normal vector. This is because the plane equation IS a dot product of a known vector and an unknown. So if you plug in an unknown vector into x,y,z them that is basically the dot product.

Intersecting planes are hilarious.

The slide he put up looked really trippy / cool when he put it up and the whole class said "woah" all at once, which was a silly response since it's just a math slide, so people felt silly about it and they all laughed at their response.

epickiller30 He put two slides on top of each other to illustrate the intersection of three planes in two steps. The students laughed because (1) the slides themselves are planes, and (2) the second slide completed the first one quite neatly: When the second slide was put up, it turned some of the dashed lines on the first slide into solid lines while leaving some intact. People thought this was sleek and the professor hit two birds with one stone. They might have also laughed because the whole thing looked briefly like a single object with dislocated parts while he was adjusting the slides.

@NguyenDung-bx8vu  MIT is well known as the marquee tech school in the world, perhaps tied with Stanford. That's not really news nor is it controversial. That aside, there are other top schools with free courses available, but not to the extent of MIT's OCW.  It's worth noting that MIT has for a very long time had a culture prone to open-sourcing. Their famous hacker culture is the epitome of this. Hell, RIchard Stallman, probably the foremost pioneer of open-source (or at least it's more extreme cousin, free software but that's only more to the point) was at MIT for decades, and did his work from there.   Universities are not as profit-motivated as your average corporation. While they certainly look out for their budget, most professors (the people who run the University) don't care so much about money as they do about their fields, and often personal prestige. I don't necessarily disagree that part of their motive is exposure, but really a lot of this is well-intentioned.   At some point you have to ask yourself: why not? Putting these courses up really doesn't cost MIT anything, it does good, and it's great for optics. Gilbert Strang and others have put a ton of work into courses on here, and they have little to gain. Potentially selling (emphasis on potentially) some books isn't going to make Strang's final years on this planet much better; the man is probably far wealthier than his wants demand. He just likes teaching people.

@matanorland1  It's because not all of the students pay all of that $50K (that's what it is now). About 85% of the students receive some sort of grants  from MIT. In order to maintain and make sure that future students will get those those scholarships they need donations.

@aakksshhaayy That question was designed to be a bit of a mindfuck. It makes you focus at answering with respect to the normal vector because that is what you have to take the inner product with and put labor. If you are not focused you don't pay attention to the last part, the actual question (and not because of stupidity as many people would rush to imply here).

@matanorland1 This is not how things work. MIT works like a corporation, and when corporations start new projects, they either allocate money for their development from a bank account or by loans. After the project is developed is must be self-sustained and cannot exist as a burden of other projects. Plus, departments compete within an corporation for funding; it's not free for all.
